subject: Ant for building native applications (Re: [junit] Sun doesn't  use JUnit. Why?)
msgSnippet: ... So am I correct to paraphrase you this way? There aren t the proper Ant tasks to support building native applications written in C/C++ . If so, then Ant s
messageBody:
>So said twall@... on 4/28/2003 --------------------
>On 28.04.2003 16:30:39, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@...> wrote:
>
>>What about Ant makes it difficult to manage widely-ranging dependencies
>>and tasks? If Ant can do what make can do, when why is Ant any less
>>suited to building the JDK/JVM than make?
>>
>>>So said Timothy Wall on 4/27/2003 --------------------
>>>Aside from neither of these existing when they originally set up the
>>>build and test processes, ant is less suited than make to managing a
>>>large, complex project that consists of a wide range dependencies and
>>
>>>tasks. Can you imaging trying to use ant to build a VM?
>>>
>
>In short, because ANT doesn't have built-in, precompiled and configured
>dependency rules and flags for things like "cc", "ld", and so on. These
>are things that
>are trivially constructed in a shell call or make dependency rules, but
>rather complex,
>verbose, and circuitous when wrapped in XML.

So am I correct to paraphrase you this way? "There aren't the proper Ant tasks to support building native applications written in C/C++".

If so, then Ant's not the problem. I'm just trying to understand, so don't feel like I'm contradicting you for the sake of it.

>Yes, ant *can* do other things besides compile sets of java files for use
>by javac and
>jar, but it's not necessarily well-suited to do so.
>It is one thing to say ant can do what make can do (after all, you can
>always write
>more Java code, right?). It is another to actually do it.

"make" was built to support the environment of the day. Ant is also built that way. You're right: Ant doesn't support "make"'s native environment very well, but that's just because no-one has wanted to do it, I guess.

Take care.
